comments.author: King Z

comments.text:
+King Z I guess so. Like at least Franklin wasn't some mindless goon, he 
actually had a good set of morals on him, so that was good definitely, 
though it's arguable as to whether he was the "noblest" character in GTA V 
despite being the fairly out-of his depth newbie that many games seem to 
promote as their characters. I get this sense people like Trevor, although 
homicidal maniacs, didn't ever lie to somebody or backstab them, he just 
straight up told them of their impending death and got to business, without 
bullshitting them or giving them false hope, which is arguably a very noble 
trait (Though that does bring me to think that there's never been any 
really "crazy" African-Americans in games that I've played at least, the 
most unhinged they go is just a bit zany, nothing like Trevor, for example) 
. I was gonna write Lamar as he's a pretty stereotypical funny gangbanger 
type from what I've seen/heard but for some reason I wrote Franklin instead 
:/ ah well. I'm British man, the sarcasm and alla that stuff is pretty much 
in the way I've been taught to write hahaha :) Though you're equally as 
good to talk to, I was reckoning briefly that I'd be debating over in game 
racism and representation with some positive discrimination maniac (which 
isn't the case obviously :) )
comments.author: iHuzza

comments.text:
Woah woah wooooah! I completely agree with you and appreciate your 
articulate and sophisticated response. It's been awhile since I've read 
something like that, but seriously you've gotten Franklin and Carl Johnson 
way f'ed up if you think that's what their personas were. They aren't the 
average product of their ghetto environment, in fact they are the ones that 
stand out and raise hope for the people that are in those surroundings. 
That's the only reason why those characters don't act like stupid black 
thugs. I may not be the best Afro American representation, but if anything 
I believe I speak for all that bares the same color as me, these little 
characters like Ulysses, Franklin, and CJ especially represent Afro 
Americans better than any other Afro character in a game I've seen so far, 
as far as my memory provides. But I agree with your statement, and in the 
sophisticatedly put response, I felt like you were mocking me and being 
sarcastic for some reason. But at the end of reading your response I felt 
otherwise. Don't know why I had to say that, maybe it has meaning to you. 
Idk, js I guess.
comments.author: King Z

comments.text:

mysterious and mainly philosophical set of values alongside being the 
biggest badass to ever fight in the entire series instead of the videogame 
black person basic stereotype of a sassy, amoral tough hearted and 
generally hostile+ unintelligent person. I'd go with Ulysses anyday over 
somebody like Franklin/ CJ from the GTA series.
comments.author: iHuzza

he's so into symbolism.

armor was a thing.

comments.text:
+Chester Seitz From reading this so far, you pretty much just sound like an 
asshole as the others have said. The reason this series is worded as it is 
is because they're telling things from the perspective of someone who heard 
of the events of the games, but did not experience them (aka they're doing 
actual, authentic storytelling instead of reading off of a wiki for 
everything). As you clearly can't see, they've worded everything so that 
the storyteller doesn't have all of the minute details due to only hearing 
of these events from other sources who don't have all of the answers.

comments.text:
most of ulysess' dialogue just doesnt make much sense. You can't have a 
gme's main character be a nameless unknown dude and then keep making 
refrences to things he may or may not have done in the past without any 
proof or reason. it feels tacked on
comments.author: McBlemmen

comments.text:
+Matheus Cossuol It's known, even explained in the game. Ulysses talks 
about it, and the Courier can get him to elaborate. Courier Six was 
contracted by the NCR to deliver a package to the towns of the Divide, 
where the NCR forces there would study it closer. It was sent there, 
specifically, because it shared codes found on the warheads. Little did 
anybody know, it was a remote detonator, and the whole place went up.

Some of it, though, isn't featured in the game. I always assumed it was 
deliberate on the NCR's part, but from a forum post by JE Sawyer, I found 
out it was an accident.

Interestingly, the dust storms are a Big Mountain experiment, like the 
Poison Cloud of the Sierra Madre.
comments.author: Willy A. Jeep WRE

comments.text:
Never mind this comment. I understand how the Divide disaster happened. It 
actually does make sense.
comments.author: nkorea

comments.text:
+nkorea It's assumed that someone knew of the warheads underground, and 
that person wanted to destroy the Divide, so he sent a package with an 
eyebot along with the activation codes.
My guess is that it was either NCR or Legion, as we know there are ghouls 
of both factions in the Divide.
comments.author: Matheus Cossuol

comments.text:

accidentally do this doesn't make much sense.

top_comment.text:
I hated how lonesome road was built up and then the story just didn't make 
sense, most people are going to hate on me for saying this (cause you all 
love obsidian even though fallout new vegas is the same as fallout 3) but 
the lonesome road dlc was just stupid, it gave forced your characters past 
to be written for you and it forces personality changes. Also having all 
the other DLCs build on the other one is just a bad way to try and get me 
to buy all the DLCs, still a great game, just tired of everyone sucking 
obsidians dick.﻿
top_comment.author: jessebrown1996

comments.text:
Even if you're a free lance, it still dictates that my character was a 
courier, whether or not he worked for the company doesn't change that, as 
for the whole "being hunted down by mercenaries" well that does give my 
courier some motive, it doesn't really explain why you get dragged up in a 
massive war, I mean lets face it, Mr House trusted his entire scheme on a 
courier purely on the basis that he survived a shot to the head and he can 
walk across the wasteland, in real life you would a rich business man who 
was planning this for years pick a delivery boy/girl and not have a single 
other person in mind? Same with all the other factions. Then there's the 
DLCs, I enjoyed how the built up to the final DLC, even though that pretty 
much is just them trying to get you to buy it (so that's minus points and 
positive points), but then the final DLC came out and I find out the only 
reason why this guy was following me was because I delivered a package that 
happened to blow up loads of nuclear missiles, they once again made it so 
my courier did something that I didn't know about, and it wasn't even 
something that I knew I did, all that build up, just to find out that all I 
did was deliver a package, if they're going to make my courier do 
something, at least make it something cool.
comments.author: jessebrown1996

comments.text:
+jessebrown1996 Well you are never told that you are a full on curior for 
the company.  You could just be a freelance who is working because of the 
caps.  As for the whole 'This man just shot me, I am going to kill him' if 
you read the contract (and other contracts for the same job) you would know 
that the punishment for losing or theft of the package includes being 
hunted down by mercenaries unless you can retrieve the package.
comments.author: maxbarrass1

comments.text:
The DLC forced you to have a back story, so obsidian fucked up, yes Fallout 
3 forced you to have a certain back story, but you start off as a kid so 
you make the character your own, and you decide what your character has 
done from the get go, where as Fallout New Vegas did the same thing, but 
they took it one step further and decided to pick your job for you, you say 
Fallout 3 forced you to have a dad and live in the vault, well Fallout New 
Vegas forced you to have a job as a courier before hand (you can try and 
say you can pretend you weren't but that's just silly), and you never have 
motivation other than "some guy shot me now I'm going to kill him". The 
only major difference in story between the 2 is the "which side do you 
pick" ending, which is good, but it's not enough to excuse the fact that 
Fallout New Vegas DID force you to be something, worst still is that it's a 
carbon copy of Fallout 3, just with more weapons and longer loading times. 
Fallout 3 invented the wheel, it did something unique and made you see your 
character as they grew up so you could decide there personality from the 
get go, Fallout New Vegas made the same mistake Fallout 3 did with 
character only they didn't allow me to decide what he was like from the get 
go, and they forced you to do a job that half the characters I make would 
not be caught dead doing. Fallout 3's story made sense, Fallout New Vegas 
was too much of a fantasy story.
comments.author: jessebrown1996

comments.text:
I know a tone of people that really hate Fallout: New Vegas and loves 
Fallout 3.  While they may be the same, they do have differences that some 
people will love and others will dispise.  For instance, Fallout 3's voice 
acting is fucking atrocious.  In Fallout: New Vegas, it is actually 
bearable.  However Fallout: New Vegas is rather linear, while Fallout 3 was 
pretty open from the get go.  So there are differences.  As for the 
bullshit back story, Fallout 3 had the whole bullshit back story but if 
forced you to have it.  You could not say 'nope, I don't want to have lived 
in the vault and have that man as my dad'.  No, you were forced to have 
that.  As for New Vegas, you can just ignore the back story if you so 
desired.  Now I am not hating or riding on Obsidian's dick but I do think 
that they did such a better job at presenting the narrative than Bethesta.
comments.author: maxbarrass1

top_comment.text:
Graham, Ulysses, Elija. Neil, Tabitha?  So many underdeveloped great 
characters.... The merchants not doing their job most of the times.... 
Great game, great waste of potential.... Nevermind. Another excellent 
episode!﻿
top_comment.author: o mero

comments.text: +Dirty Blue Thats just shitty :(
comments.author: xMLGx xRektx420x

comments.text:
+Nathan Bird Because Zenimax desperately wanted to cash in both the Fallout 
3 craze (by making another game like it) and the Fallout 3 hate (by 
bringing in the people who worked on the first two and putting it back on 
the west coast) as soon as possible.

It's easy to forget that this came out a mere 2 years after Fallout 3. 14 
months of development, in that case, means that they started this less than 
10 months after Fallout 3, and wanted it done fast enough that people were 
still going crazy about it.
comments.author: Dirty Blue

comments.text:
+Dirty Blue If they gave it more time, it might have been an even more 
amazing game. Why did they only have 14 months?
comments.author: xMLGx xRektx420x

comments.text:
+Nathan Bird Yep. Compare that to, say, Halo, or even fallout 3, which were 
about 2-3 years in development, and you can see why New Vegas was somewhat 
unpolished.
comments.author: Dirty Blue

comments.text: +Webemperor1 Wait... Fallout nv was made in 14 months?
comments.author: xMLGx xRektx420x

comments.text: Dev had little time to make this game. You can't blame them.
comments.author: Internetowy Żołnierz przeszukujący Internet w celu niszczenia trolli, idiotów i głupot

comments.text:
+Dirty Blue Game was made in a matter of 14 months. There would be an 
entire Legion city, thrice more Legion quests, much more endings, many more 
decisions, many more accessible areas and many more quests. But Zenimax had 
to fuck it all up.
comments.author: Webemperor1

comments.text:
+Webemperor1 Yeah, not counting the pre-development (first draft scripts, 
concept art, design framework, etc.) the game was made in, what 8 months? 
If this had been given the same dev time as Fallout 3 - a couple years, at 
least - it could have been revolutionary.
comments.author: Dirty Blue

comments.text: Zenimax forced Obsidian to rush FNV and it's DLCs. That's the reason.
comments.author: Webemperor1

comments.text:
I really don't think any of those except maybe Neil and Tabitha are 
underdeveloped. Elijah, Ulysses, and Graham's stories all interconnected 
and generated a grand interweaving narrative that is New Vegas and its DLC.
comments.author: Zeldarulah

comments.text:
+ShadowCastPro I'm saying in-game, and specifically in FO:NV. Those three 
are just rail-roading you through a planned path. Conversation with them is 
a rather dull exercise, as opposed to the interaction with other 
characters... I'm considering a character underdeveloped when the options 
dealing with them is less straightforward than either please them or... I 
was really impressed by Chief Hanlon and Caesar's conversations, also 
arguing with Col. Moore was an interesting moment. Even not fully sketched 
characters can be effective... Bitter Root, Dr. Hildren, Orion Moreno, Ada 
Strauss... I can count more minor characters with more impact on the game 
that those tree supposed "major" characters. All in all, I suspect they 
were very much helped by "out-of-game" talks, more than their actual role 
"inside-the-game". My opinion, of course. Cheers!
comments.author: o mero

comments.text:
How is Ulysses and Graham undeveloped? There's tonnes of back story to them 
that HAS been told, Elija also has been mentioned quite a bit and as for 
Neil and Tabitha, not too bothered about them tbh.

top_comment.text:
Question of  the Week: Ulysses was originally supposed to be a companion in 
Fallout New Vegas, but was cut from the final version of the game and now 
appears in the Lonesome Road DLC. Of all the characters you've encountered 
in your wasteland travels, which do you want to see make an appearance in 
Fallout 4? More importantly, WHERE THE F$%# IS FALLOUT 4?!?!
Unlock the Fallout Lore Audio Book | http://www.patreon.com/ShoddyCast﻿
Follow us on Facebook | http://Facebook.com/ShoddyCast
Follow us on Twitter | http://twitter.com/ShoddyCast﻿

comments.author: colebowlin68

comments.text:
+Samuel .Lescelius Someone keeps flagging you and its pissing me off... 
Anyway haha, I can see your point. To each their own. My main problem is I 
usually like power trip type games so difficulty puts me off if it doesn't 
hook me in elsewhere.
comments.author: EliteRanger_

comments.text:
+EliteRanger_  Ahahaha! Okay I gotcha. I never had that much trouble with 
the enemies. Even though I played a fairly weak female character (just for 
realism and roleplay I started her up with very little strenght and 
endurance, but of course by the time I got to the point where I started the 
DLCs she was fairly well off with all important skills) and with high 
difficulty plus hardcore mode. I did still feel like I wanted to take a 
break and sometimes the stress of it all really got to me, but I still 
loved it overall and in the end I cherished even the hardships I had to 
endure. I actually enjoyed it more than Lonesome Road, which is number 2 of 
my DLC preferances. LR uncovered so many things and was just a blast of 
awesome and tragic at the same time, plus I respect the hell out of Ulysses 
and thought he was the most interesting character of all in the whole game, 
but still an even bigger part of me and especially my character stayed 
behind in Sierra Madre for some reason. The whole place just felt like 
something I'd actually enjoy in some very strange way and when I finally 
had the chance to get the hell outta there, I wanted to stay, but there was 
nothing to do.
comments.author: Samuel .Lescelius

comments.text:
+Samuel .Lescelius It was mostly a joke actually haha. First off, I loved 
the story of it and even the atmosphere and characters. The gameplay, 
however was horrendous imo. I never liked melee weapons and that was the 
only thing that worked okay on the enemies. Speaking of enemies they were 
such a pain to kill. Also the cloud things were a bit of a pain. Also the 
fact that you couldn't leave and take a break (while it made sense 
story-wise) drove me mad. But, I have played worse, just don't ask me to 
play it again. I got the story, Im done haha.
comments.author: EliteRanger_

comments.text:
OMG this describes my feeling too! I think NV had a better story but FO3 
had a better feeling for post apocalyptic
comments.author: Bojangler123

comments.text:
+EliteRanger_  Why don't we speak about Dead Money?
I LOVED Dead Money. And it did connect into the main game.
I've heard many different opinions on why people don't like it, but most 
seem to dislike it for either the atmosphere and the fact it felt more like 
a horror game, some didn't like it because of the radios and all the things 
that made you constantly stand on your toes etc.
But I don't see why the DLC being challenging and different in gameplay 
should make anyone forget about or overlook the amazing story and 
characters the DLC brought to the table.
And I just LOVE the ghost people.
I'd really like to hear your reason for why you don't talk about Dead 
Money? I may be poking a hornets nest, but my curiosity exceeds the limit 
where I care.
comments.author: Samuel .Lescelius

comments.text:
+SqueakyBaluga I also loved honest hearts and old world blues. All of the 
DLCs had a story that was connected to each other and the main game. We 
don't speak about dead money. But that said excluding dlcs I would still 
pick New Vegas because FO3s original ending annoyed the crap out of me, 
even if New Vegas went a similar route.

everything bad that happened to him. Not just that, but he is unable to 
move on from the past, and is too scared to end it all by his owns hands, 
so he had to involve you. Despiste his big words, he acts just like a 
scared child would.
Lonesome Road is probably my least favorite of the dlcs. The Divide wasnt a 
interesting place to explore, and Ulysses wasnt half the character I 
expected him to be, so I was really disappointed.﻿
top_comment.author: Nyarulathotep TheCrawlingChaos

comments.author: Blake Bias

captions.text:
You've experienced the FALLOUT series in your
own way, but want to learn more about its

story. Well- to get to the heart of the story-
you have to go back to the beginning...

There were some mighty inhospitable places
in this world even before the war. Deserts

that could sear the life from a man as fast
as any radioactive crater, rivers so polluted

they'd catch fire, and lawless lands ruled
by brutal fanatics. It was a bad enough place

that some people even looked forward to the
apocalypse; a chance for humanity to start

over and build a new society that was worthy
of its people's loyalty. There are some folk

who are proud to wear the flags of the new
societies that have appeared in the aftermath.

The Brotherhood, the Enclave, New California
Republic -- even some slaves in the Legion

who are proud of the bull symbol embroidered
on their clothes. But the flags of the old

world are still out there for travelers who
care to look. The red, white and blue, and

the stars and stripes appear all over the
Mojave. They're a code. A message for someone.

Can't say who they're for, but the man who
made the marks isn't shy about making his

presence known.
He traveled throughout the Mojave as a messenger

of the Mojave Express out of Primm, concealing
his role as one of Caesar's Frumentarii. He

calls himself Ulysses. That's a name from
the old Roman times, and one that belonged

to a general who fought in one of America's
most bitter wars. The Mojave's Ulysses named

himself after this general, a hero who united
two nations under a single flag. America's

flag on his back is a symbol of that dedication.
That is just one example of his beliefs. Ulysses

is a man who respects symbols. He spent his
life trying to find one that he could be proud

to wear. It began with the tribe he was born
into, the Twisted Hairs. They wore their hair

in braids to symbolize their life and achievements,
and Ulysses has honored that tradition throughout

his life, even after the tribe was assimilated
by Caesar's Legion.

He's a loyal man too, and that is a both a
virtue and a curse in the Wasteland. Despite

seeing his tribe betrayed and enslaved by
Caesar, Ulysses still remained loyal to the

Legion. Give that man a cause, and he'll fight
under its flag.

He carried the symbol of the bull with him
throughout Nevada and was the first in the

Legion to discover Hoover Dam, where he spotted
the Rangers from the New California Republic.

The Rangers had their own flag, their totem
was the two-headed bear of the NCR. These

were men who shared his respect for symbols,
and Ulysses knew that the bull and bear would

battle to the death over that dam.
He didn't fight in the battle for Hoover Dam

himself. Caesar had sent him further West
to cut the NCR's supply lines. Interstate

15 used to be a highway where cars and trucks
rolled at speeds faster than a deathclaw on

Jet. Two centuries after the war, it was known
as the Long 15, and it saw its fair share

of traffic with brahmin carts bringing food
and ammunition to NCR soldiers. The road served

as a jugular vein for the bear's two heads.
Shortly before the NCR clashed with the Legion

at the Dam, Ulysses was out by the Long 15,
in a town called Hopeville. That's the sort

of name they liked to give places back before
the war. Putting the word "Hope" in the

name didn't save the place when the Great
War struck, though. Got hit pretty bad, and

it took years before folk started settling
back in. Seems there was a courier who frequented

that route on trips between California and
the Mojave. Funny that Ulysses and this other

courier could walk the same roads for years
and never meet face to face, but that other

courier helped build up Hopeville and neighboring
town of Ashton. The place was looking mighty

promising a few years ago thanks to the work
of that one courier.

Ulysses saw the symbols of the old world in
that restored community. He realized that

the stars and stripes had the potential to
be greater than the Bear and Bull combined.

Hopeville and Ashton could have been a new
home for him, free of the war between the

Legion and NCR. A starting point for a nation
that was worthy of his loyalty.

But hidden away under those towns was a secret.
No one knew that back before the war, they

were actually used to hide missile silos.
Those atomic warheads had slept nice and quiet

for two hundred years, like mythological beasts
from a primeval past. Whatever old world talisman

was supposed to wake them for the Great War
never arrived.

Well, it didn't arrive until a couple of years
ago. Without warning, the missiles started

launching and exploding, right under the towns.
It was the second time Armageddon, and it

ripped the land open, torn the streets, filled
the ground with invisible radioactive fire,

and sent up dust storms that could skin a
man alive. Why did they suddenly detonate,

after all that time? The only person who made
it out of there was Ulysses, and whatever

he knew about it, he's kept to himself so
far.

Even though he escaped, there are still some
souls living in the ruins of Hopeville. The

NCR soldiers and Legion troops who were fighting
over the place when the warheads blew are

trapped there now. The radiation changed them,
mutated them into something akin to the ghouls

we have in the rest of the Wasteland.
The harsh sandstorms flayed them alive, but

their mutation kept them going even with their
skin scoured off. Their red, exposed flesh

marks them as the unfortunates who survived
a second apocalypse, and their rage unites

them against anyone who enters their land.
Their identities as NCR or Legion are gone.

The only vestige of those former lives are
the scraps of old uniforms they wear.

Luckily, they grow weak when they stray from
the radioactive soil of this place they call

The Divide now. Few people have laid eyes
on them except for a couple of couriers and

a foolhardy storyteller in rusty power armor.
Ulysses managed to escape with his hide intact

because of the automated medical technology
in the Divide. The place was full of robots,

including those little floating eyebots that
the Enclave used to have out East. There must

have been pre-war machinery in the Divide
that could duplicate the eyebots, and modify

them to do the work of auto-docs.
After climbing out of the ruins of the Divide,

Ulysses was still loyal to Caesar for a time.
Before he took his final trip back to the

Divide, he was sent by the bull to the Great
Salt Lake in Utah. There he manipulated the

White Legs tribe into doing Caesar's will.
He would inflict the same fate that had befallen

his own tribe onto the White Legs, all to
kill one man.

Joshua Graham was one of the few men that
Caesar feared had allied himself with another

tribe in the area, so Ulysses taught the White
Legs how to wage war with Roman brutality

and twenty-first century weapons. The White
Legs were unaware that their alliance with

the Legion would eventually be their undoing,
and they hailed Ulysses as a hero, and honored

him by mimicking his braided hair. They still
wear it that way today, unaware that he considered

it to be a mockery of his dead kinsmen, the
Twisted Hairs.

His days of meddling with the tribals of Utah
might have been the breaking point of his

loyalty to the Legion. Not long after that
he took to wandering the wasteland pursuing

his own goals. He set about destroying the
new America that seemed hell bent on repeating

the mistakes of the old.
He knew that a weather station in a place

called the Big Empty was connected to the
sandstorms in the Divide, so he trekked into

the deepest parts of the wasteland to find
it. There he braved the roving bands of lobotomized

slaves and attack robots to restore the Divide,
and maybe the spirit of America too.

He left his marks while he was there, but
he didn't leave many more after that. His

travels must have taken him all over the Mojave
and beyond, but all we know is that he was

in the town of Primm recently. The log books
at the Mojave Express office there show that

he was hired to take something important to
the New Vegas strip, but he turned down the

job. Some other courier took the package,
whatever it was.

After that, Ulysses disappeared back into
the Divide. He left a series of messages behind

him as he went, most of them addressed to
another courier. Courier Six. Maybe that's

the same courier who used to travel through
the Divide years ago, or the courier who took

that last job at the Mojave Express. Whoever
it is, Ulysses was calling them to the Divide

for some reason.
Maybe someone answered that call already.

A mushroom cloud went up over the sky near
Hopeville a while ago. Could have been Ulysses

settling a score with that courier, although
he'd have to have one Hell of a grudge if

it involved nuking that town for the third
time.

Ulysses has seen his tribe destroyed, his
new home shattered, and loyalty spurned. He

turned to the old world when the new one failed
him. He's a man who could make any spot in

the wasteland his home, but he chose to stay
in the Divide because of what it symbolized

for him.
Lately there's been a person out there in

the ruins above Hopeville, keeping a lonely
vigil over the broken land. Has the lean body

of a messenger, and wears the flag of the
Old World on their back. It might be that

other courier wearing a duster like the one
that Ulysses used to wear. Or it might be

Ulysses himself. After years of living only
for his hate, he might have made peace with

himself, and the courier. The wasteland has
enough problems already, and lots of folk

would find it comforting to think that Ulysses
has come to the end of his journey, delivered

his final message and is content to stand
guard over one place for a while.

Ulysses was one of the greatest assets the
Legion had, but even he was far from the deadliest.
But that- is a story for another day...
